results.title: The Syrian Civil Defence
results.brief_description: Hospitals under siege, constant firefights, the Syrian Civil Defence sifting through bombed buildings. Millions of videos of the Syrian Civil War have been recorded and uploaded to YouTube and online platforms, but has all this footage made any difference?
results.description: Hospitals under siege, constant firefights, the Syrian Civil Defence sifting through bombed buildings. Millions of videos of the Syrian Civil War have been recorded and uploaded to YouTube and online platforms, but has all this footage made any difference?

results.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

constellations_primary.name: Outlawed
constellations_primary.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.description:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
description_for_label:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

results.title: The Simpsons arcade cabinet
results.brief_description: The Simpsons arcade game set itself apart from other brawlers and TV game properties with the show’s main cast voicing the characters, who have unique weapons to swing at enemies. Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t use a three-wood golf club.
results.description:
The Simpsons had only screened one season when Konami released this side-scrolling beat em up in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew how successful The Simpsons would be, it’s that they already had the foundation for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied the same mechanics to The Simpsons, which featured almost identical play style and button mashing combat. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions, with the TV show’s main cast voicing the characters in the game.

Players can control either Homer, Marge, Bart or Lisa as they use unique fighting techniques – punching or swinging a vacuum cleaner, skateboard or skipping rope – to rescue Maggie after she’s kidnapped by Smithers.

Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t swing a three-wood golf club.
description_for_label:
The Simpsons had only been on-air for one season when Konami released this four-player side-scrolling ‘beat em up’ in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew what a phenomenon The Simpsons would become, it’s that they already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the successful Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied the same mechanics to The Simpsons, which featured almost identical play style and two-button combat.

What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of everyone’s favourite Springfield residents, with the TV show’s main cast voicing the characters in the game. Players control either Homer, Marge, Bart or Lisa as they use unique fighting techniques – punching, swinging a vacuum cleaner, skateboard or skipping rope – to rescue Maggie after she’s kidnapped by Smithers. Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t swing a three-wood golf club.

results.title: The Road Warrior publicity images
results.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Bursting with stunning practical effects, explosive set pieces and iconic costumes, the original Mad Max trilogy (1979–85) cemented its place in pop culture before roaring back to life 30 years later.

results.title: The Power of Love
results.creator_credit: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.brief_description: The first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience was The Power of Love (1922), which used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour.

constellations_primary.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.description:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.
description_for_label:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.

results.title: The Pitch
results.brief_description: Films aren’t always plotted from start to finish. In animated films, teams of artists often develop scenes and stories that are then performed to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film. This is the ‘pitch’ and it’s an integral part of storyboarding.

constellations_primary.name: The Pitch
constellations_primary.description: Explore fantastical worlds and underwater seascapes.

results.description:
Films aren’t always plotted from start to finish. In animated films, teams of artists often develop scenes and stories that are then performed to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film. This is the ‘pitch’ and it’s an integral part of storyboarding. Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers, storytellers and visual artists.

Conrad Vernon was a storyboard artist on Shrek (2001) and co-director on Shrek 2 (2004), as well as the voice of the Gingerbread Man in the series. In this scene from Shrek, Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man to find the whereabouts of Duloc’s exiled fairytale creatures.

Tom McGrath was a storyboard artist, writer and co-director on the Madagascar trilogy, as well the voice of Skipper in the series. In this scene from Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa (2008), the zoo animals take off in a rickety plane with high hopes of it returning them safely to New York City.
description_for_label:

In animated films, teams of artists often develop scenes and stories that are then performed to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film. This is the ‘pitch’ and it’s an integral part of storyboarding. Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers, storytellers and visual artists.

Conrad Vernon was a storyboard artist on Shrek (2001) and co-director on Shrek 2 (2004), as well as the voice of the Gingerbread Man in the series. In this scene from Shrek, Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man to find the whereabouts of Duloc’s exiled fairytale creatures.

Tom McGrath was a storyboard artist, writer and co-director on the Madagascar trilogy, as well the voice of Skipper in the series. In this scene from Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa (2008), the zoo animals take off in a rickety plane with high hopes of it returning them safely to New York City.
